subject: RE: [junit] RE: Why doesn't JUnit count asserts
msgSnippet: How come Management just wants to know Quantity (how many tests?, How many assertions (I don t see the usefulness)?. Is this the way to measure Quality?... I
messageBody:
How come Management just wants to know Quantity (how many tests?, How many
assertions (I don't see the usefulness)?. Is this the way to measure
Quality?...

I would insert my assertions in each test based on class(es)
responsibilities. If management wants to know if all the assertions are
inserted then should possibly review the test manually or if management
wants to keep an eye on someone then they should develop there own tools to
do that. If somebody is not careful enough to put these assertions then he
is not doing a good job. JUNIT is not for POLICING SUCH things or Junit is
not a metric report generator. Its a light-weight framework that you could
use it to quickly develop tests and run against your code.

At the end of the day QUALITY MEANS "HOW MUCH YOU CARE". You will know HOW
MUCH YOU CARED when a customer of your product finds a problem or a bug.

Understood, and thanks for bringing us back to the point of the thread. My
final words on the subject: if management cares about how many assertions
there are, then before long, so will the developers. If you don't want them
to care, then you should consider finding a way for management to get the
information they want without counting assertions.

An interesting discussion. Thanks.

Since I started this whole debate off...

I want to make very clear that the only reason we counted asserts was for
the mgmt. team's sake. The developers could care less. Also, the
developers didn't care exactly how many tests were written. What we wanted
to know was that we had tested everything that could possibly break. End
of
story for us.

-Jason
